properties.Info: A good collection of Cairns and an ancient hill fort stand on the eastern side of the Preseli Mountains. A cairn is a manmade pile of stones with a history going back thousands of years and often associated with a burial site, as here at Foel Drygarn
A beautiful stretch of Pembrokeshire coast in the national Park
A beautiful stretch of Pembrokeshire coast in the national Park

Links.title: Laugharne Castle and Dylan Thomas's boathouse home

properties.Info: The island is owned by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and has dramatic cliffs for sea birds as well as heath land. It is also one of the most important breeding ground for Grey Seals. The island has only two human residents � the warden and his wife who live in a small farmhouse

This is the smallest city in the UK and the final resting place of St David, the Patron Saint of Wales. In 1123 the Pope granted a Papal Privilege upon St David�s, making it a centre of pilgrimage for the Western World. As a result the present cathedral was begun in 1181 to cope with the increase in pilgrims

Solva was once a major trading port during the medieval period and an important centre for lime burning. The sheltered harbour today attracts holidaymakers and boat owners, who can then explore the dramatic coastline.

Horatio Nelson described the deep water harbour as the finest port in Christendom. It was in the 1960�s that the first oil terminal opened, and in recent times a new Liquid Natural Gas terminal has been built, which will be able to handle around 25% of the UK�s gas requirements

Soon after the Battle of Hastings the Normans looked to conquer Wales and in 1093 the first Pembroke Castle was built. Over the next hundred years or so the castle took on the form, we see today, and it was here that the future Henry VII was born, who became the first Tudor king.
A beautiful section of coastline with Caldey Island in the distance, home to a Cistercian monastery
Retaining its early Victorian charm Tenby is a classic seaside resort. Two beaches almost surround the town, which sits on a peninsular opposite St Catherine�s Island

This is a rare example of a medieval open field system on a hill above the village of Laugharne. Each strip is separated by a raised ridge and each villager would have been allocated a number of strips. In many ways the modern system of allotments is a type of open strip farming.

properties.Loc: Laugharne Castle and Dylan Thomas's boathouse home
properties.Info: Laugharne Castle overlooks the River Taf and a few hundred metres upstream is a small Boathouse where Dylan Thomas lived between 1949 and 1953 with his wife Caitlin and children. It was here that he wrote Under Milk Wood

properties.Loc: Wharley Point and River Towy estuary
properties.Info: With beautiful beaches and woods tumbling down to the sea the Towy Estuary is a spectacular place and popular with visitors

properties.Loc: River Towy from sea to Carmarthen
properties.Info: The Towy is the longest river which entirely runs through Wales. It rises in the Cambrian Mountains and flows out into Carmarthen Bay. The river is noted for trout and salmon fishing

From the Black Mountains in the west to the Usk River in the east the Brecon Beacons National Park encloses roughly 500 square miles of spectacular landscape. With few roads the Brecons is a great place for fell walkers, though the weather can be very fickle
The mountain is 598 metres high and offers stunning views across the Black Mountains and down to the Bristol Channel. The name drives from the old fashioned way of buying sugar in a solid cone shape

Beautifully sited in the Vale of Ewyas the Augustinian priory goes back to the early 12th century, and was the first in Wales. By the early 13th century the priory had become one of the great medieval buildings in Wales until it gradually fell into ruin following the Dissolution of the Monasteries

This is the second largest castle in Britain after Windsor, and was built in a concentric style between 1268 and 1271. From the air it is an impressive sight with the main part of the castle built in a lake, and the gatehouse on another island
In 1871 the eccentric Marquess of Bute built this Gothic Revival Castle on the remains of a 13th century one, and is a true fairytale castle

Cardiff is the capital and largest city in Wales. The Norman castle sits on a mound within the old Roman walls and alongside the Marquess of Bute�s neo-medieval revival one. Close by is the Millennium Stadium

The regeneration of Cardiff Bay has been one of the most successful projects of its type in Britain. From industrial decline and dereliction the bay has been transformed into a thriving concern along with a new Welsh Assembly, and an opera house. A large lock system to the sea has created a 500 acre freshwater lake

Links.title: Laugharne Castle and Dylan Thomas's boathouse home

properties.Info: Newport was once one of the major South Wales ports handling the coal that fuelled the Industrial Revolution, but in the 20th century began a steady decline as industry began to collapse. The port is now a shadow of what it once was

The Roman amphitheatre is associated with the Arthurian legend by Geoffrey of Monmouth in his Historia Regum Britanniae written during the 12th century. It has been suggested that the round arena is the basis for King Arthur�s round table. However, this legend has to compete with several others places in Britain associated with Arthur

These are some of the most spectacular monastic ruins in Britain and have been painted by JM Turner as well as poems about it composed by Alfred, Lord Tennyson and William Wordsworth. Tintern was the first Cistercian abbey in Wales and begun in 1131

Links.title: River Towy from sea to Carmarthen

properties.Info: Over thousands of years the River Wye has carved a deep gorge in the limestone and created one of the most visited places in the region. Woods cascade down to the river with a few exposed rocks in places, which in some cases provide a viewing platform. The valley is a breathtaking sight, especially from the air

The castle keep was begun just one year after the Battle of Hastings in 1067, and is the oldest stone fortification in Britain. It was built on a good crossing point of the River Wye and was a useful base, as the Normans set about conquering Wales. Over the next few centuries it was slowly added to until by the end of the 17th century it began to fall into decay

This was the first castle in Edward�s I �Iron Ring� of fortresses that would eventually extend right around North Wales to Harlech in the West. Building began in 1277 and took nine years and 1,800 labourers to complete. A tidal moat once separated the inner ward and an outer bailey, and the castle could be supplied from the sea

Bangor is one of the smallest cities in the UK and dates back to the early 6th century and the founding of a monastic establishment. The word �Bangor� is an old Welsh word for a type of fenced-in enclosure. The University, which swells the town with over 8,000 students, was established in 1884

Snowdon is the highest mountain in England and Wales at 1085 metres. It has also been described as the busiest mountain in the UK because of the number of people who climb it, as well as the thousands who go up by the steam train. In 2009 a new mountain top station and caf� replaced a rather ugly older one
Crib Goch is what is known as a knife-edge Ar�te, which is French for �fishbone�. At 923 metres it is a dangerous place for unwary climbers and there have been several fatalities over the years

Links.title: Snowdon Train on lower half of mountain

properties.Loc: Snowdon Train on lower half of mountain
properties.Info: The railway is the only public rack and pinion one in the UK and has been in operation for more than a hundred years opening in 1896. The single track has passing loops along the way in order for trains to pass. The trains start from Llanberis and there are several halts and stations along the route.
Also known as Meini Hirion in Welsh and Druid�s Circle in English the stone circle is one of the finest in Wales. It has thirty stones, with ten still standing

Two historically important bridges cross the Menai Straits, the first is the Britannia road and rail bridge of 1850, which was largely re-built in the 1970�s following a fire, and the earlier suspension bridge of Thomas Telford from 1826, which was the first crossing over the straits

Because Beaumaris was never finished, or used, it ironically remains in a better condition that most other castles. This was the last fortress in Edward I�s Iron Ring, and building took place for thirty five years from 1295. The moat was filled by a tidal lock

This is one of the great Norman revival mock castles of the early 19th century complete with a great keep. It is estimated that it may have cost around �150,000 to build, which in today�s money is close to 50 million pounds. It was built for the Pennant family, who had made a fortune from nearby Bethesda slate mining and Jamaican sugar

Overlooking the small town of Llanfairfechan is a quarry, which in the early 20th century employed over a thousand men, many of whom would have lived in the town. The extracted granite was exported not only to Liverpool but too many other major UK cities.

This is one of the few castles in north Wales, which was built in the early 13th century by Llywelyn ap Gruffydd, Prince of Wales. It was later captured by Edward I in 1283 and strengthened by adding a new tower, now in ruins. It returned to Welsh hands in 1404 when Owain Glyndwr took the castle and then largely destroyed it.
Powis Castle has gradually been turned from a fortress into a house with a rare and beautiful terraced garden from the late 17th century, which has survived the 18th century fashion for landscaping.

These very rare farm buildings were built in the mid 19th century and based around the principles of Prince Albert�s farm in Windsor Great Park. It had its own gas works, water powered turbine and even a funicular railway to transport manure slurry to a storage tank. The circular buildings allowed carts to turn around
This is a beautiful valley in the Cambrian Mountains to the east of Dolgellau
Twenty turbines stand on a hill just outside the village of Trefenter, and have been here since 1993
Sited on a rocky promontory above the River Teifi Cilgerran Castle was built in the 13th century. From its high position it could attack with a catapult any invading ship coming up-river
The Preseli Mountains are now part of the Pembrokeshire Coast National Park. It was from here that the Bluestone is believed to have been cut and transported to Stonehenge to create the inner circle
A small valley leading up to the mountain of Moel Sych in the Berwyn range of hills

The mountains technically stretch from South Wales to Snowdonia, but in more modern times has come to refer to the mountains in Mid Wales. They are a wild and often desolate place, but also very beautiful and a popular place for walkers and climbers. Two great rivers, the Wye and the Severn, rise in them. The highest point in the range is 752 metres.

This is the highest peak in the Aran mountain range and the highest British mountain south of Snowdon. It is also nine metres short of being a member of the Welsh 3000�s (feet). Due to its remoteness it is not as popular as other mountains to visit, but it is a dramatic sight from the air

The castle is a good example of one built by the Welsh Princes, as opposed to one built by the English. However, in 1277 shortly after the castle had been completed, and without the approval of Edward 1, it was taken by the English, who then altered parts of it. By the late 14th century the castle was already in a state of poor repair and was finally abandoned

Montgomery is an historic county town in the Welsh Marches, with many fine houses lining the grid plan layout. On the hill is the ruined castle, which was begun in 1223 and formed part of the English defence along the Welsh border. It was attacked several times, but was never taken by Welsh forces. Ironically the town and castle are now in Wales

The castle we see today was probably built sometime in the late 1260�s by the local Welsh prince. It was eventually taken by the English then regained by the Welsh before finally being taken back by the English. It must have been a hard castle to take on top of its high hill

Rhyl is a seaside town, which was very popular in Victorian times. By the 1970�s with cheap package holidays on offer Rhyl�s popularity declined dramatically. New investment programmes have been started to revive the town�s fortunes

Links.title: Bodnant Garden on the River Conway

properties.Info: The estuary is a major wildlife area and one of the most important in Britain. Seals bask on the sandbanks and the patterns left in the sand and mud by the retreating tide looking wonderful from the air

It was Edward I who built the castle we see today as part of his �Iron Ring� of castles across North Wales. It survived two Welsh attacks in 1294 and 1400, but by the 16th century it had begun to deteriorate and finally during the Civil War was partly demolished to make it useless as a fortress

The vast Victorian house was begun in 1871 and took five years to build. It had fifty two bedrooms and staff quarters for another 60. It even included a room for just ironing the newspapers so that the print did not come off on people�s hands. Today the house stands empty waiting for a new lease of life

properties.Loc: Bodelwyddan Castles and 1st WW trench training area
properties.Info: Between 1830 and the 1850�s the original castle house was turned into a sort of fantasy castle and was further embellished in the 1880�s. Part of the grounds were used for trench warfare training during the First World War, and traces of the trench work can still be seen

Links.title: St Asaph and cathedral (smallest in Britain)

properties.Loc: St Asaph and cathedral (smallest in Britain)
properties.Info: It is often claimed that St Asaph�s is the smallest cathedral in Britain. The earliest parts of the present building date from the 13th century after Edward 1 burnt down the previous one in 1282. But it was in the Tudor Age that the building was finished and then greatly restored during the 19th century

Links.title: Bodnant Garden on the River Conway

properties.Loc: Bodnant Garden on the River Conway
properties.Info: This large and beautiful garden was begun in 1874 and in a sense has gone on ever since. It is divided into two parts � the upper level around the house with Italianate terraces, and the lower level, called the Dell, with a wooded valley full of specimen trees

This was one of the wonders of its age and people travelled from far and wide to see it. Completed in 1805 it is 307 metres long, 38 metres high with a 16 metre span between the 19 pillars. The width is only 3.4 metres, just enough for a barge and towpath

Links.title: Bodelwyddan Castles and 1st WW trench training area

properties.Info: This is a mountainous area on the eastern side of the Snowdonia National Park. Foel-Fras itself is 942 metres high

The lake stands in the shadow of Tryfan, a mountain where it is said that Sir Bedivere, one of the Knights of the Round Table, is buried. Llyn Ogwen claims an even greater legend as the resting place for King Arthur�s sword Excalibur. True or not the lake is a beautiful place and popular with anglers

We owe it to Thomas Telford, the 18th century engineer, for re-building the A5 road, which goes through to Holyhead and takes you along the southern shore of Llyn Ogwen before dropping down into the impressive Nant Ffancon Valley

Snowdon is the highest mountain in England and Wales at 1085 metres. It has also been described as the busiest mountain in the UK because of the number of people who climb it, as well as the thousands who go up by the steam train. In 2009 a new mountain top station and caf� replaced a rather ugly older one
